title: onepromptSite Home Page
prompt:
Create a homepage for a project called
  "OnePromptSites" ‚Äî a visually striking, modern directory that
  showcases websites created from a single AI prompt.
    
    The homepage should include:
    
    ‚Äì Title: ‚ÄúOnePromptSites‚Äù
    ‚Äì Below the title, show a subheading that cycles slowly every few seconds
  between the following SEO-visible phrases with a soft fade transition:
    ‚Ä¢ One prompt, one site ‚Äì infinite possibilities.
    ‚Ä¢ Microstartups, macro inspiration ‚Äì all built with a single prompt.
    ‚Ä¢ One idea. One prompt. Zero code. Witness the magic.
    ‚Ä¢ From prompt to product: see one‚Äëprompt wonders in action.
    ‚Ä¢ AI alchemy ‚Äì turning a one‚Äëline prompt into a live website.
    ‚Äì Below the subheading, include this static intro paragraph:
    "OnePromptSites is a curated archive of websites created from a single
  AI prompt. Each entry reveals the exact prompt used, the tools involved, and
  honest insights into what worked (and what didn‚Äôt). It's a behind-the-scenes
  look at how far one good prompt can go."
    ‚Äì Under the intro paragraph, in smaller italicized text:
    "Built from one core AI prompt (with only minor edits for
  polish)"
    ‚Äì Beneath that, add a simple horizontal visual flow: OnePrompt ‚Üí Site ‚Üí
  Launch
    
    Use the following JSON as the data an example of format to provide the code
  in:
  [https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dgriff86/oneprompt-json-host/refs/heads/main/1prompt.json](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dgriff86/oneprompt-json-host/refs/heads/main/new1prompt.json)
    
    For each site entry:
    ‚Äì Show a screenshot using `previewImage` if present
    ‚Äì If missing, render a fallback card with:
    ‚Ä¢ A clean, readable background
    ‚Ä¢ Centered title
    ‚Ä¢ Label: ‚ÄúPreview Not Available‚Äù
    ‚Äì Below the preview:
    ‚Ä¢ Title (clickable, opens `url` in new tab)
    ‚Ä¢ Date (from `createdAt`) in format like "May 12, 2025"
    ‚Ä¢ A toggle dropdown: "View Prompt" ‚Üí expands to show the full
  `prompt` in a <pre> block, styled with high contrast and includes a
  ‚ÄúCopy Prompt‚Äù button positioned at the top of the expanded area
    ‚Ä¢ Optional toggle: "Build Notes" ‚Üí show if any of the following
  are present: `tool`, `whatWorked`, `whatDidntWork`, `nextSteps`
    ‚Äì If `notes` exist, display them subtly
    ‚Äì If `projurl` exists, display a small link or button labeled ‚ÄúVisit Live
  Site‚Äù (opens in new tab)
    
    Below the card list:
    ‚Äì Paginate results (10 per page), sorted newest to oldest
    ‚Äì Navigation control at the bottom: ‚ÄúPrevious / Next‚Äù
    
    Sponsor Block:
    ‚Äì If a sponsor image URL exists in the project code, show it in a styled banner
    ‚Äì Else show default:
    ‚Ä¢ Heading: "Sponsor this site"
    ‚Ä¢ Subtext: "Get featured here ‚Äî email
  [sponsor@onepromptsites.com](mailto:sponsor@onepromptsites.com)"
    
    SEO & Metadata:
    ‚Äì Title: OnePromptSites
    ‚Äì Meta description: A growing archive of websites built with one prompt
  alone.
    ‚Äì Use default social image if none provided
    
    In public folder:
    ‚Äì Create a blank file named `sitemap.xml`, leave empty for manual
  updates
    
    Favicon:
    ‚Äì Include standard <link rel="icon"> markup in <head>
  pointing to a favicon relevant to the site, using the provided image. Save
  this as `favicon.ico` in the public root folder. This favicon must be
  manually added to the directory.
    
    Footer:
    ‚Äì Centered: ‚ÄúBuilt with AI ¬∑ One prompt at a time‚Äù
notes:
Showcase of prompt generating the home page. Some
  text edited in code directly after the prompt.
whatWorked:
Simple and straightforward, I‚Äôve been refining my
  personal GPT to learn what works best.
whatDidntWork:
1 code fix automatically cycled. I found that
  trying to force a specific theme through detailed wording often restricted
  the AI too much. Instead, I started attaching a reference image of the style
  I wanted, that shift made a huge difference in how well the results matched
  my vision.
nextSteps:
Use this as the base for fivepromptsites.com. Might
  take this off oneprompt to make it easier to manage in the future.

title: GymBro Home Page
prompt:
Create a fully functional, mobile-first single-gym website
  named "onepromptGymBro" that includes:
    
    - A public-facing user view
    - A gym owner/admin dashboard
    - Toggle-based layout switching with proper state management
    
    Design should reflect brands like F45 or CrossFit ‚Äî clean, bold, minimal,
  and optimized for mobile.
    
    ---
    
    Header & Toggle Controls (Responsive & Functional)
    
    - Fixed top nav bar with onepromptGymBro logo
    - View toggle with 2 options:
    ¬† - ‚ÄúUser View‚Äù
    ¬† - ‚ÄúAdmin View‚Äù
    - On mobile:
    ¬† - Use a dropdown or tab switcher
  for compact toggle
    ¬† - Ensure tap targets are
  touch-friendly
    - Clicking a toggle:
    ¬† - Updates a `viewMode` value in
  localStorage (e.g., `user`, `admin`)
    ¬† - Re-renders the page content based
  on the selected mode
    - On page load:
    ¬† - Check localStorage for last used
  `viewMode`
    ¬† - Default to "User View"
  if none found
    - Each view must conditionally render its section ‚Äî only one active view at
  a time
    
    ---
    
    User View (Public Site)
    
    - Hero section with gym branding and CTA
    - Enquiry form (name, email, phone, message)
    ¬† - Stores to localStorage and shows
  confirmation
    - Daily Workout (pulls latest "Published" workout)
    - Class Schedule (pre-filled or synced from Admin)
    - Mobile-friendly footer
    
    ---
    
    Admin View (Gym Owner Dashboard)
    
    - Leads Panel
    ¬† - Table of enquiries with notes +
  follow-up email
    ¬† - ‚ÄúConvert to Member‚Äù opens modal
  with sign-up
    - Members Panel
    ¬† - List of members with editable
  info
    ¬† - Send Welcome/Exit emails
    - Workout Manager
    ¬† - Add/edit/delete workouts, mark
  one as ‚ÄúPublished‚Äù
    - Class Scheduler
    ¬† - Weekly grid of gym classes with
  fields
    
    ---
    
    Data Handling
    
    - All data in localStorage: enquiries, members, workouts, schedules
    - View toggle must persist and reflect changes live
    
    ---
    
    Styling
    
    - Responsive layout, sticky headers, collapsible panels on mobile
    - Tabs, cards, and modals for clean UX
    
    ---
    
    User Stories
    
    1. As a visitor, I want to submit a contact form.
    2. As a visitor, I want to view the daily workout.
    3. As a visitor, I want to browse the class schedule.
    4‚Äì11. As a gym owner, I want to manage leads, members, workouts, and
  schedules with proper feedback and flow.
    
    ---
    
    Build Guidelines
    
    - No backend, only localStorage
    - View toggle must:
    ¬† - Set `viewMode` in
  localStorage
    ¬† - Load correct view on
  refresh
    ¬† - Ensure only active view content
  is rendered
notes:
Showcase of prompt generating the home page. Some
  text edited in code directly after the prompt.
whatWorked:
This is my first site on bolt. Not sure I love it but will
  continue testing
whatDidntWork:
You can't force to much through AI. I really wanted a member
  login section as well member engagement functions but the prompt just got too
  sophisticated and AI couldn't keep up.
nextSteps: Member Portal + Health Tracking + Booking + Billing

title: EXCEL to JSON Home page
prompt:
Create a mobile-first web app that lets users paste Excel or
  Google Sheets data ‚Äî including complex, multiline cells ‚Äî directly into an
  interactive HTML table. This table should be editable, convertible to JSON,
  and support clean output formatting.
    
    ---
    
    CORE GOAL¬† 
    Enable a seamless paste-from-Excel experience that accurately renders
  pasted tables (including line breaks within cells) and allows real-time
  editing, conversion, and download as JSON.
    
    ---
    
    PASTE & TABLE INPUT¬† 
    - Use a large, styled `<div contenteditable="true">` as the
  main paste zone.
    - On paste:
    ¬† - Intercept clipboard HTML using
  `e.clipboardData.getData("text/html")`
    ¬† - Extract the `<table>`
  element from the pasted content
    ¬† - If no table is found, display a
  gentle error message
    - Render the extracted table visually, maintaining:
    ¬† - Row/column structure
    ¬† - Line breaks, paragraph spacing
  inside cells
    ¬† - Merged cells as separate values
  (optional: flatten colspan/rowspan)
    ¬† - Multiple rows of header data, if
  present
    
    ---
    
    TABLE RENDERING¬† 
    - Display the table inside a styled, scrollable card with `rounded-2xl`,
  `shadow`, and `p-4`
    - Each cell should be editable using `contenteditable`
    - Maintain a JSON object behind the scenes that stays in sync with
  edits
    
    ---
    
    CONVERSION & OUTPUT¬† 
    - Provide the following output tools:
    ¬† - ‚ÄúConvert to JSON‚Äù button ‚Üí
  creates structured array with headers as keys
    ¬† - ‚ÄúCopy JSON‚Äù button ‚Üí copies final
  output
    ¬† - ‚ÄúDownload JSON‚Äù button ‚Üí
  downloads file
    ¬† - Optional: "Copy as CSV"
  or "Download as .csv"
    - Preserve special characters, embedded line breaks, and whitespace in
  output
    - Output JSON should be pretty-printed, with a toggle for minified
  output
    
    ---
    
    POWER FEATURES¬† 
    - ‚ÄúClear Table‚Äù button ‚Üí resets the entire paste/render area
    - Find & Replace functionality:
    ¬† - Search within entire table or
  specific column
    ¬† - Replace globally or
  per-match
    - Toggle for schema preview (key:type)
    - Toggle between raw JSON view and table view
    - Optional: Detect headers if missing and prompt user to define them
    
    ---
    
    VISUAL DESIGN¬† 
    - Tailwind-style UI:
    ¬† - Paste area: `border-dashed`,
  `p-4`, `text-gray-600`
    ¬† - Table: clean white background,
  subtle border, zebra striping
    ¬† - Cells: `hover:bg-gray-100`,
  editable cursor
    - Responsive: works on mobile and desktop
    - Smooth transitions when data is pasted, cleared, or toggled
    - Footer: ‚ÄúBuilt with love ¬∑ One prompt at a time‚Äù (centered, sticky on
  mobile)
    
    ---
    
    ADVANCED OPTIONS (optional toggle drawer)¬†
  
    - Merge rows with shared keys
    - Validate field types
    - Export multiple tables (if detected) as separate JSON objects
    - Detect and split multiple tables if pasted in one go
    
    ---
    
    SEO & BACKEND¬† 
    - Include blank `sitemap.xml` in `public/`
    - Title: ‚ÄúPaste Excel to Table to JSON‚Äù
    - Description: ‚ÄúPaste Excel tables into editable HTML and export to clean
  JSON instantly.‚Äù
    - Meta viewport + favicon
    
    ---
    
    This project should feel magical: paste ‚Üí render ‚Üí edit ‚Üí export. No
  uploads. No config. Just flow.
notes:
The site was built to make my life easier. There are other
  converters but wanted easy copy and paste from excel tables.
whatWorked:
Great simple clean site. Something I'll be using for my
  projects going forward.
whatDidntWork:
Lovable didn't build in a new favicon so stuck with the default‚Ä¶ Site should
  have been named onepromptEXCELtoJSON. Code was manually edited. Google AdSense slot request was
  ignored by AI, will need to add it manually later if this concept works.
nextSteps:
I would like support for multiple tables in one JSON to simulate multi-table
  database structure. If successful, plans to remix into fivepromptSites concept.

title: CafeConcept Home page
prompt:
Build a fully functional, mobile-first caf√© website called
  Caf√© Concept using this JSON as the complete data source:
    
    JSON URL:¬† 
    https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dgriff86/oneprompt-json-host/refs/heads/main/cafecocept.json
    
    ---
    
    Site Structure and Views
    
    1. Landing Page (Welcome View)¬†
  
    - A warm hero section with the caf√© name, a short welcome blurb, and a soft
  background image¬† 
    - A clear call-to-action button labeled "Browse Our Menu" that
  scrolls or transitions to the menu view¬†
  
    - Optional elements include opening hours, location, or daily special
    
    2. Menu View (Customer Order Mode)¬†
  
    - Load categories sorted by their sort_order field¬† 
    - Display menu_items grouped under each category¬† 
    - Use a compact, mobile-first grid layout with two tiles per row on mobile
  and three or more on larger screens¬†
  
    - Each menu tile should show the name, description, base price, and
  availability status¬† 
    - Tapping a menu item opens a modal for selecting available add-ons,
  sourced from addon_groups¬† 
    - Enforce rules for required selections and multiple selections where
  applicable¬† 
    - Add-on pricing should update the item total dynamically¬† 
    - A floating cart icon or sticky footer should summarize selected
  items¬† 
    - When the "Place Order" button is clicked:
    ¬† - Route items to the correct prep
  queue based on their prep_area
    ¬† - Clear the cart completely
    ¬† - Display a temporary confirmation
  message such as "Order Submitted" for at least three seconds
    
    3. Prep Queues (Barista and Kitchen Split)¬†
  
    - Every menu item includes a prep_area field that designates it as either
  barista or kitchen¬† 
    - Orders should be automatically split into two separate queues based on
  prep_area¬† 
    - Each queue operates independently and tracks items with statuses: queued,
  in_progress, and done¬† 
    - Changing the status of an item in one queue should not affect items in
  the other¬† 
    - Only the last three completed items should be displayed in each
  queue¬† 
    - Older completed items should be auto-archived¬† 
    - Optionally include a manual "Clear Completed" button
    
    4. Admin Panel (Local Menu Editor)¬†
  
    - A local-only admin interface using localStorage to persist changes¬† 
    - Allow full CRUD (create, read, update, delete) functionality for:
    ¬† - menu_items
    ¬† - categories
    ¬† - addons
    ¬† - addon_groups¬† 
    - Editable fields should include: name, base price, category, prep_area,
  and availability¬† 
    - Admins should be able to assign or remove addon groups from menu
  items¬† 
    - Include a button labeled "Download JSON" to export the current
  data structure as a file
    
    5. Front-of-House Table Entry View¬†
  
    - A staff-facing interface to enter and manage table orders¬† 
    - Allow selection or entry of a table number¬† 
    - Let staff build an order using the full menu UI, including addon
  selection¬† 
    - Optionally support item-specific notes such as "no sugar" or
  "allergy: dairy"¬† 
    - Once submitted, items should route automatically to their respective prep
  queues¬† 
    - Display a list of active orders by table and optionally allow marking
  them as paid or closed
    
    ---
    
    Navigation and View Switching
    
    - Include a persistent navigation bar or tab menu that allows switching
  between these four views:
    ¬† 1. Menu View (Customer)
    ¬† 2. Prep Queues (Barista and
  Kitchen)
    ¬† 3. Admin Panel (Local
  Editing)
    ¬† 4. FOH Table Entry (Staff
  Use)
    
    ---
    
    Styling and UX
    
    - Design should be mobile-first with responsive layouts for all
  screens¬† 
    - Layout and typography should take inspiration from high-end Australian
  caf√©s such as Industry Beans or Proud Mary¬†
  
    - Prioritize compact menu cards, clean white space, and clear visual
  hierarchy¬† 
    - Use smooth transitions, swipe-friendly interactions, and sticky action
  buttons for better mobile usability¬†
  
    - Use a neutral, modern color palette with no visual clutter¬† 
    - Add a footer with the message: "Built with love ¬∑ One prompt at a
  time"
    
    ---
    
    Fixes and Logic Notes
    
    - After submitting an order, always clear the cart by resetting its
  state¬† 
    - Display a clear "Order Submitted" confirmation message that
  remains visible for at least three seconds¬†
  
    - Ensure barista and kitchen queues are handled independently and never
  sync their states automatically¬† 
    - Limit displayed completed orders in each queue to the three most recent
  items
    
    ---
    
    General Notes
    
    - All menu and structure data should be loaded directly from the external
  JSON file¬† 
    - Do not hardcode any menu content¬†
  
    - All admin edits should persist locally using localStorage¬† 
    - No backend services or login functionality are required¬† 
    - The website should continue working offline after the initial load
notes:
I'm so happy with how this turned out! Tested out serving
  dummy database tables through a JSON file and the functionality is awesome!
whatWorked:
Functionality and menu admin is way better than expected. Can
  edit and manage everything from pricing to add-ons. Separate kitchen and
  barista queues for workflow works well.
whatDidntWork:
8 code fix cycles. Minor bug that you can‚Äôt return
  to landing page once in the menu. Customer initiated orders don‚Äôt provide the
  option to enter name or table numbers. Favicon updated in a single separate
  prompt. Lovables favicon anoys me.
nextSteps:
Booking system > Billing and tax > Discounting and
  Specials

title: I present Promptosauris
prompt:
Create a polished, professional web app called ‚ÄúPromptosauris‚Äù
  ‚Äî a focused workspace for browsing, customizing, and managing AI
  prompts.
    
    Use the following JSON as the data source:
    https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dgriff86/oneprompt-json-host/main/promptosauris.json
    
    Each prompt includes:
    - category (string)
    - promptName (string)
    - prompt (string, may include [TOPIC])
    
    ---
    
    Purpose:
    Designed for professionals who regularly use AI tools in their workflows.
  Users can quickly explore categorized prompts, personalize them with a topic,
  and copy or pin frequently used ones for reuse.
    
    ---
    
    Layout Overview:
    
    1. **Header**
    - App name: ‚ÄúPromptosauris‚Äù
    - Subtext: ‚ÄúA smarter way to manage prompts‚Äù
    - Top-right theme toggle (light/dark)
    - Favicon: clean dinosaur icon or stylized ‚ÄúP‚Äù
    
    2. **Global Topic Field**
    - Input labeled: ‚ÄúSet your topic to personalize prompts‚Äù
    - Placeholder: ‚Äúe.g. financial planning‚Äù
    - Automatically replaces `[TOPIC]` wherever used
    - Store in localStorage
    
    3. **Pinned Prompts**
    - Display fixed above prompt list if any prompts are pinned
    - Show compact tags or rows with:
    ¬† - Prompt name
    ¬† - Quick copy and remove
  buttons
    - Include "Copy All" to copy full list at once
    
    4. **Navigation & View Toggle**
    - Sidebar or sticky top nav on desktop, dropdown on mobile
    - Filter by category or toggle:
    ¬† - ‚ÄúAll Prompts‚Äù
    ¬† - ‚ÄúPinned Prompts‚Äù
    - Optional search bar with live filter (name, category, content)
    
    5. **Prompt Display**
    - Clean, compact prompt rows
    - Each includes:
    ¬† - Prompt name
    ¬† - Buttons: View, Copy, Pin
    - Expanded view shows full prompt (with `[TOPIC]` applied)
    - Keep spacing tight and button grouping consistent
    
    6. **Personalized Prompts**
    - If `[TOPIC]` is set:
    ¬† - Show separate section: ‚ÄúPrompts
  for: [TOPIC]‚Äù
    ¬† - Filtered list of prompts
  containing `[TOPIC]`
    ¬† - Appears above other
  categories
    
    7. **Smart Suggestions (Optional)**
    - Below each prompt or section, show ‚ÄúYou might also like‚Ä¶‚Äù based on
  category or usage
    - Simple links or chips ‚Äî no clutter
    
    8. **Responsive Ad Units (Optional)**
    - Support Google AdSense (optional key-based load)
    - Show ads only if a valid key is supplied
    - Recommended positions:
    ¬† - After topic input
    ¬† - Above footer
    - Ads should not appear between prompt rows
    
    ---
    
    Styling:
    
    **Overall Aesthetic:**
    - Professional, minimal, and neutral
    - Prioritize clarity, whitespace, and hierarchy
    - No visual clutter or excessive color
    
    **Light Mode (default):**
    - Background: #FAFAFA
    - Font: modern sans-serif (e.g. Inter, Helvetica, Source Sans)
    - Cards: subtle borders, light shadows
    
    **Dark Mode:**
    - Background: #121212
    - Text: #E0E0E0
    - Buttons and accents: muted blues or teals
    
    ---
    
    üíæ Logic & Functionality:
    - All data is static, loaded from JSON
    - No backend or login required
    - Use localStorage for:
    ¬† - Theme preference
    ¬† - Pinned prompts
    ¬† - Topic input
    
    - Ensure:
    ¬† - Mobile responsiveness
    ¬† - Keyboard accessibility
    ¬† - Fast search + no reloads on
  interaction
    
    ---
    
    ¬†Footer:
    Include subtle footer:¬† 
    ‚ÄúPromptosauris ¬∑ Built with AI ¬∑ One prompt at a time‚Äù
    
    ---
    
    ¬†Developer Notes:
    - Detect and replace `[TOPIC]` dynamically across preview, copy, and
  pin
    - Never mutate or overwrite original JSON
    - Ensure layout remains performant for >100 prompts
    - Keep prompt rows and action buttons clean, consistent, and tightly
  grouped
notes:
This is a simple easy to use prompt library. I found it hard
  to get something I liked! Actually pretty hard designing something that's
  simplistic and easy enough to use. I'm 80% happy with this.
whatWorked:
Starting functionality was good with some minor clean ups
  required like removing categories from tiles.
whatDidntWork:
It was difficult to get a UX that I was somewhat happy with
  it.
nextSteps:
Clean up the content. Think I can make the prompt library way
  better with more curated prompts.

title: Strong Prompt Pool Services
prompt:
Create a professional, visually clean, and mobile-optimized
  website for a pool services company named
  "onepromptPoolServices".
    
    **Branding and Visual Design:**
    - Use a minimalist design with a color palette that evokes cleanliness and
  relaxation, such as shades of blue and white.
    - Incorporate high-quality images of pools, maintenance work, and satisfied
  customers.
    - Ensure consistent use of fonts and colors throughout the site to
  reinforce brand identity.
    
    **Homepage:**
    - Feature a prominent hero section with a clear value proposition and a
  compelling call-to-action (e.g., "Schedule Your Pool Service
  Today").
    - Include a brief overview of services offered with links to detailed
  service pages.
    - Display customer testimonials with real names and photos to build
  trust.
    - Highlight any certifications or affiliations to establish
  credibility.
    
    **Services Page:**
    - List all services offered, such as pool cleaning, maintenance, repairs,
  and inspections.
    - Provide detailed descriptions for each service, including benefits and
  what customers can expect.
    - Use icons or images to visually represent each service.
    
    **About Us Page:**
    - Share the company's mission, values, and history.
    - Introduce the team with photos and short bios to personalize the
  business.
    - Mention any awards, certifications, or notable projects.
    
    **Gallery Page:**
    - Showcase before-and-after photos of pool projects.
    - Organize images into categories (e.g., cleaning, repairs, installations)
  for easy navigation.
    - Ensure images are optimized for fast loading without compromising
  quality.
    
    **Contact Page:**
    - Include a contact form with fields for name, email, phone number, and
  message.
    - Provide multiple contact options: phone number, email address, and
  physical address with an embedded Google Map.
    - Add social media links for platforms like Facebook and Instagram.
    
    **Additional Features:**
    - Implement a blog section to share pool maintenance tips, company news,
  and industry updates.
    - Ensure the website is responsive and functions seamlessly on all
  devices.
    - Optimize the site for search engines with appropriate meta tags, alt text
  for images, and keyword-rich content.
    - Include a favicon by uploading a separate .ico file and linking it in the
  HTML head section.
    - Add a footer with the text: ‚ÄúBuilt with love ¬∑ One prompt at a time‚Äù,
  centered and styled to match the site's aesthetic.
notes:
Design test, am I over engineering? Detailed prompt - Easy
  pool cleaning site. Well designed and easy to navigate and is one prompt
  worthy.
whatWorked: Clean design and user experience from the start.
whatDidntWork:
Images seem to be a bit of a pain. I tried to
  prompt more in but with no luck. Will work if you try and refine I suppose.
nextSteps:
Continue testing elaborate design approaches in prompts. The
  detailed prompt is at minimum equal to the auto designed one.

title: Basic Prompt Pool Services
prompt:
Build me a really awesome pool cleaning website for a business
  in Sydney Australia called onepromptPoolCleaning
notes:
Design test, am I over engineering? Very basic prompt - Easy
  pool cleaning site. Pretty good also.
whatWorked: Clean design and user experience from the start.
whatDidntWork:
Looked less pool servicy with less images. Less images gives
  less room to break I suppose.
nextSteps:
Continue testing elaborate design approaches in prompts. The
  detailed prompt is at minimum equal to the auto designed one.
